data.title: British Road Race Championships
data.meta_description: United Kingdom Track and Field All-Time Lists - Results of British Road Race Championships.
data.text:
AAA ROAD RACE CHAMPIONSHIPS

AAA of England Championships were open to all-comers until 1st September 1996 from which time individual events have usually been limited to athletes affiliated to English clubs and, prior to 2001, competing in their club's vest (although other athletes were still permitted to compete as guests).

AAA MARATHON CHAMPIONSHIPS

The men's championship was first held in 1925. The women's championship, introduced in 1978, was held under the auspices of the WAAA from 1978-82 and 1988-91, the WCCA from 1983-84 and the WCC&RRA from 1985-89. The event has been held in conjunction with the London Marathon since 1983. The 1980 women's championship was awarded to the leading English or Welsh finishers in the Avon International Marathon, and the 1983-90 women's championship to the leading English or Welsh affiliated athletes in the London Marathon. The 1993 men's and women's championships, and those held since 1997, were restricted to English athletes (and from 1997-2000 also resticted to athletes wearing club vests). This section lists first three finishers since 1960. Winners of Championships from 1925-1939 and 1946-1959 can be found on pages for those eras.

Venues - Men: 1960 Welwyn Garden City, 1961 Enfield, 1962 Welwyn Garden City, 1963-64 Coventry, 1965 Port Talbot, 1966 Windsor-London (Ch), 1967 Baddesley Colliery (Nuneaton), 1968 Cwmbran, 1969 Manchester, 1970 Windsor-London (Ch), 1971-72 Manchester, 1973 Harlow, 1974 Windsor, 1975 Stoke, 1976 Rotherham, 1977 Rugby, 1978 Sandbach, 1979 Coventry, 1980 Milton Keynes, 1981 Rugby, 1982 Gateshead, 1983- London

Venues - Women: 1978 Isle of Wight, 1979 Sandbach, 1980 London, 1981 Rugby, 1982 Windsor, 1983- London

AAA ROAD RELAY CHAMPIONSHIPS

The AAA first staged a men's 12 stage road relay championships in 1967, although prior to this date the London to Brighton Road Relay had assumed the status of a national championships. The women's championships, first staged in 1963, were held under the auspices of the WCC&RRA until 1992. The AAA Young Athletes Championships moved from autumn to spring in 2003. This section lists results since the events introduction.

Venues - Men's 6 Stage & Boys (Autumn): 1969 London (CP), 1970-71 Southport, 1972 Leeds, 1973 Keele, 1974-75 London (WP), 1976 Southport, 1977 Melton Mowbray (Asfordby Hill), 1978 London (CP), 1979 Southport, 1980 Melton Mowbray (Asfordby Hill), 1981 London (CP), 1982 Derby, 1983 Melton Mowbray (Asfordby Hill), 1984 Thamesmead, 1985 Manchester, 1986 Sutton Coldfield, 1987 London (CP), 1988 Derby, 1989 Sutton Coldfield, 1990 Aldershot, 1991 Chorley, 1992 Sutton Coldfield, 1993 Aldershot, 1994 Sunderland, 1995- Sutton Coldfield

Venues - Women's 4 Stage & Girls (Autumn): 1963A Huyton, 1965S Friern Barnet, 1966S Sheffield, 1967S Newcastle-under-Lyme, 1967A Aldershot, 1968 Lancaster, 1969 Bristol, 1970 Barnet, 1971 Bradford, 1972 Newcastle-under-Lyme, 1973 Uxbridge, 1974 Derby, 1975 Newcastle-under-Lyme, 1976 Harlow, 1977 Bradford, 1978 Coventry, 1979 Leyton (Eastway), 1980 Rossendale, 1981 Leicester, 1982 Banbury, 1983 Liverpool, 1984 Keele, 1985 Aldershot, 1986 Liverpool, 1987 Birmingham (Un), 1988 Aldershot, 1989 Lincoln, 1990- Sutton Coldfield

YOUNG ATHLETES ROAD RELAY CHAMPIONSHIPS

The championships, first held in 1983 under the auspices of the National Young Athletes League, were not held in 1987 as the event was switched from Autumn to Spring. Girls championships were first held in 1998. uk:athletics took over the running of the event in 2002, however did not organise a championships after that date.

MORPETH TO NEWCASTLE ROAD RACE

First run as a handicap race in 1902 and a scratch race in 1904 the Morpeth to Newcastle, traditionally held on New Year's Day, was the oldest running annual road race in Britain. The event switched to a later date in January in 2002 and was discontinued after 2004. Originally held over a distance of 13 5/8 miles, the course was changed to 14.1 miles in 1983 and to the Half Marathon distance in 2002. Women were first allowed to enter in 1982. The greatest number of wins was 7 by Dunky Wright (1927-32 & 1934). This section lists winners since 1960.

LONDON TO BRIGHTON ROAD RELAY

The News of the World first organised the London to Brighton Road Relay in April 1925, although Surrey AC had also staged a race in 1924. With the growth in popularity of road relays the London to Brighton was restricted to teams from the southern counties in 1950, however in 1951 adopted the status of an unofficial "national" championships with an additional race for southern teams only introduced in October. Clubs qualified for the "national" event based on their positions in the previous "southern counties" London to Brighton, Manchester to Blackpool and Edinburgh to Glasgow road relays respectively. The event was last staged in April 1965. The race started from Westminster (race distance of 54 miles) from 1925-36 & 1954-65 and from Mitcham (race distance 45.5 miles) from 1937-53. The race comprised 10 stages from 1925-53, 11 stages from 1954-April 1957 and 12 stages from October 1957-1965
